summary:
Interdisciplinary professional with a background in urban planning and mechanical engineering - topical areas include Climate Resilience and the Energy Transition. Lived, studied, and worked in the US, Singapore, and India and currently pursuing my joint MS degree from TU Delft and Wageningen University in Amsterdam, Netherlands. 

The degree focuses on Sustainable Urban Development through the lens of technology, data, and policy solutions with Amsterdam as our test bed. It emphasizes metropolitan solutions in the areas of urban energy, mobility, water and waste management, and food security. 

I am passionate about addressing socioeconomic equity through critical resource & and infrastructure management (water & and energy) using my background in urban planning and engineering. In my projects, I strive to develop multi-stakeholder solutions that bridge the community, private, and public sectors. My skill set includes public-interest planning methods like stakeholder engagement and co-creation, and technical skills like data analysis, geospatial studies (GIS), and engineering modeling. I work in the context of Western cities currently and have begun taking up projects in the Indian context with my current Master's thesis. I have a keen interest in working with other Global South regions as my career develops and contributing to the topics of livable cities and planning for urbanization.

projects.title: MSc. MADE Urban Living Lab: Drought Resilient Bajeskwartier - Amsterdam
projects.description: This 4 month consultancy project was part of the MSc. MADE Living Lab course and our team of 5 directly worked with the Bajeskwartier consortium in Amsterdam to develop a drought resiliency plan for their mixed-used neighborhood looking forward into 2085. Bajeskwartier is a rejuvenation project in South-East Amsterdam, where an old prison complex is being converted into a mixed-use neighborhood with residential, commercial and educational buildings. The project area spans 8 hectares and current design plans propose around 70 gardens to keep the neighborhood green. The development has already been designed and construction has begun, with the project consortium recently identifying drought as a scope. As students at the AMS Institute, this is where we contributed by 1. identifying drought risk for greenery on site from now to 2085, and 2. proposing engineering and nature-based interventions through stakeholder discussions and technical modeling. My role within the project entailed developing the cohesive design approach (synthesizing and selecting appropriate interventions.) I focused on concepts like a decentralized water grid (combining rainwater collection and storage), contributed towards a water-shortage python model, and structured co-design sessions with project stakeholders along with other team members. My personal project learnings were technical modeling (schematic water grid design, python models for droughts) and integrated process design for urban planning projects.

projects.title: Wageningen University Urban Greenhouse Challenge: Social Impact Edition - Washington, DC
projects.description:
Award: Resident Choice Award, 3rd place 
Project site: Washington, DC Ward 7
Project scope: urban farm that alleviates the food desert condition & serves as a community landmark 
Publication: https://www.ishs.org/chronica-horticulturae/vol62nr4

The WUR Urban greenhouse challenge was a 9 month long competition. The challenge was to address the food desert condition experienced in Washington DC, Ward 7, by designing a local farm that increases fresh-food access and doubles as a space for community interaction and education. 

I was part of team AMS Caterpillars and served as the Technical Design Leader, coordinating the engineering, architectural and agricultural concepts. AMS Caterpillars finished the challenge strong, winning the resident choice award from resident's of Ward 7, and finishing 3rd place as judged by the WUR UGC panel of experts. 

Our vision statement: Fostering community spirit through an adaptive, self-sustaining urban farm that ensures local food security and economic viability, infrastructure longevity and meaningful public space. Guided by this, we proposed a farm masterplan that included: a central community center (the Butterfly Building), a robust outdoor growing landscaping plan, and indoor growing with a greenhouse. the concept farm sported 25 crops. 

As a team based in Amsterdam and the AMS Institute, we linked dutch concepts like developing the farm into an Urban Living Lab which allows for community input and ownership. And being international, interdisciplinary members we tackled everything from architectural building design, HVAC systems for greenhouses, and a detailed agricultural study of crop cycles and symbiotic crop selection. The social context was the backdrop for all design decisions, with our social and economic teams conducting detailed studies of local context. We ensured a design for residents of ward 7 that not only increases their access to healthy vegetables, but also helps bolster their socioeconomic prospects.

projects.title: Bs. Mech Eng Capstone Project: Biofouling in Hydro Turbines - Boston
projects.description:
Client: Boston University Institute of Sustainable Energy 
Awards: Societal Engineering Award for Senior Capstone 2019 - 2nd place

Project Motivation: Exploring low-head hydropower (5kW-100kW) design options to help small rural communities become self sufficient and less reliant on the grid. 

Project Statement: A study of the limiting factors that negatively impact the power output of a hydro turbine.

Problem Statement: Biofouling (growth of microorganisms ranging anywhere from biofilms to barnacles) reduces efficiency of hydro turbines up to 60% by adding mass and surface roughness to turbine blades, increasing drag. This project aims to test different, environmentally friendly, antifouling methods and quantify the relationship between turbine efficiency and biofouling in small-scale hydro turbines. 

Testing Methodology: The project included testing various nontoxic anti-fouling methods and submerging them in the Mystic River for 45 days to observe growth, along with the construction of a data acquisition system and testing rig to measure the efficiency of these turbines. 

Collaborators and Special Thanks to:
Dr. Jacqueline Ashmore & Boston University’s Institute for Sustainable Energy
Dr. Somnath Basu
Russ Cone & Still Water Design, Inc.
Professor James Bird & Mark Menesses
Professor Greg Blonder
Professor Frank Di Bella
Professor Enrique Gutierrez-Wing
Professor William Hauser
Professor Anna Thornton
Joe Estano & the EPIC Staff

profile_positions.description: I am pursuing my MSc. thesis with the International Water Management Institute, Delhi office and I'm studying rural-urban linkages in groundwater management. I am taking a transdisciplinary approach in understanding groundwater use in urbanizing regions of the the Ramganga Basin, and my methods include spatial data analysis, community engagement on the field, extensive literature & policy reviews, and expert interviews with different levels of governance & engineering representatives. Final recommendations will include a series of opportunities & barriers along spatial design, governance and community lenses for groundwater recharge ponds' scaling-up in the region.
profile_positions.title: MSc. Thesis Internship - regional planning for groundwater, India

profile_positions.description: I was interning with Gemeente Amsterdam on the LIFE project and this position is continuing forward through the other project partner - Johan Cruijff ArenA
profile_positions.title: Graduate Student Intern - Energy Transition

profile_positions.description:
I am helping with stakeholder engagement tasks on the Local Inclusive Future Energy (LIFE) City Platform - a smart-grid project for Amsterdam Zuidoost that is a collaboration between Municipality of Amsterdam, the AMS Institute, Johan Cruijff Arena and other private & public partners. 

My role includes data analysis and stakeholder communication using data-insights for LIFE. It is a study internship alongside my MSc. in Metropolitan Analysis Design & Engineering (MADE) at the AMS Institute and my hope is to further dive into the urban energy scope of city planning, with LIFE being a great opportunity to learn the socio-technical elements and data-informed stakeholder engagement for the Energy Transition.
profile_positions.title: Graduate Student Intern - Energy Transition

profile_positions.description:
During my time at Cannon I was also part of the NEXT Council, a council for young leaders within the firm.  It was a group of dynamic, multi-faceted employees that collaborated closely with firm leadership. Together, council members acted as a catalyst for the practice’s evolution―a think tank for innovation, improvement and growth. 

By advancing ideas and innovations from frontline designers to the firm’s top levels, we advocated for the next generation of CannonDesign. We also advised our firm’s leadership on actionable solutions, innovations and services that help differentiate CannonDesign as a leading design practice.

My specific contributions focused on implementing Public Interest Design at the firm, and better connecting different office locations, like the Mumbai Office. I also received personal mentorship on career development from the firm's Chief of HR and CFO.
profile_positions.title: NEXT V Council Member

profile_positions.description:
My work involved a split between HVAC design and high performance building energy analysis. Worked on over 25 new-construction and renovation projects across the US spanning Healthcare, Higher Education, K-12, and clean rooms & labs.

HVAC design: drafting, load calculations, equipment selection for ventilation systems. Software used - Revit, AutoCAD, Trane Trace 700

Energy Modeling Lab: Code compliance, LEED, and energy cost budget models. Software used - EnergyPro, Trane Trace 700, Equest, EnergyPlus, OpenStudio, Revit Analysis

US & International building code knowledge: ASHRAE 90.1, 170, 62.1, IECC, California Title 24, LEED BD+C, LEED Healthcare
profile_positions.title: HVAC Engineer and Building Energy Analyst

volunteer_experiences.description: Just Streets is a non-profit organization working in homelessness policy advocacy in the Greater Boston Area. We are a collective of young professionals volunteering in our communities under various initiatives that spread awareness and hold our local representatives accountable. As Head of Strategic Partnerships I establish relationships with private, public and governmental organizations to identify areas for collaboration and help advance legislation at the state senate and house levels.
